'''''Lactarius controversus''''', commonly known as the '''Blushing Milkcap''', is a large funnel-capped [[fungus]] within the genus ''[[Lactarius]]'', which are collectively known as 'milk caps'. They all exude milky drops (lactate) from the flesh and gills when damaged. It has no common [[English names for organisms|English name]].

==Taxonomy==
Accredited to [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]], one of the fathers of [[mycology]].

==Description==
It is distinguishable mainly by its pinkish-buff gills and rosy markings on the upper [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] surface, often arranged in concentric rings. Like other fungi in the genus, it has crumbly, rather than fibrous, flesh, and when this is broken the fungus exudes a white milky liquid. Mature specimens are funnel-shaped, with [[decurrent gills]] and a concave [[pileus (mycology)|cap]]. It has firm, tough flesh, and a [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] which is shorter than the fruitbody is wide. The [[spore print]] is creamy-pink in colour.

''L. controversus'' is similar to several white milk-caps in the genus ''[[Lactifluus]]'' which however are only distantly related: The 'fleecy milk-cap' ''[[Lactifluus vellereus]]'', its sister species ''[[Lactifluus bertillonii|Lf. bertillonii]]'', and the 'peppery milk-cap' ''[[Lactifluus piperatus|Lf. piperatus]]'' all lack the pinkish gills and 'rosy' [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] markings.
[[File:Lact.cont(2).jpg|left|thumb|200px|Underside, showing pinkish gills.]]
[[File:Lact.cont(3).jpg|left|thumb|200px|Close up showing rosy cap markings]]

==Distribution and habitat==
It is found in [[Great Britain|Britain]], and [[Europe]], and usually grows with species of [[Salix]] (Goat willow or Creeping willow) on heaths and moors. It is uncommon.<ref name="Phillips06">{{cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006  | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6}}</ref> It is widespread in [[North America]] growing with [[aspen]], [[Populus|poplar]], and [[willow]]. Found in the aspen forests of the Sierra Nevada, and has been noted in New Mexico.<ref name="Arora2nd">{{cite book |author=David Arora |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }}</ref>

==Edibility==
This mushroom is considered inedible in western Europe due to its very acrid taste, but is eaten, and even commercially collected, in south-eastern European countries such as Serbia and Turkey.<ref>https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Miona_Belovic/publication/276868135_Edible_mycorrhizal_species_Lactarius_controversus_Pers_1800_as_a_source_of_antioxidant_and_cytotoxic_agents/links/55db171408aeb38e8a8a6e4e/Edible-mycorrhizal-species-Lactarius-controversus-Pers-1800-as-a-source-of-antioxidant-and-cytotoxic-agents.pdf?origin=publication_detail,</ref>
